awd_titl_txt: Reflected-Light Polarization Imaging to Quantify Tissue Microstructure and Damage
awd_abstract_narration:
Tendons and ligaments transfer forces from muscle to bone or between bones.  They are made of collagen that is susceptible to both mechanical and chemical damage.  Collagen damage can change the stiffness and strength of tendons or ligaments to cause pain and disability. It is difficult to study this type of tissue injury because we don't have good laboratory methods to see the damage as it occurs.  This research will use a new imaging technique that can see tissue changes during mechanical loading.  A novel video camera that sees properties of light that are invisible to the human eye will record how the linear structures of the tendons and ligaments are broken by loading that causes damage.  Visually following the degradation of the collagen during the process of mechanical degeneration will make it possible to test new methods to prevent damage or to treat the injuries. The research will train graduate students in advanced biomechanics methods.  The project includes writing a multimedia iBook on ligament and tendon function to improve interactive workshops for K-12 students and to make it easier to give biomechanics educational materials to the community.

The objective of this research is to use polarization imaging to advance the microstructural analysis of connective tissues and link the dynamic organization of soft tissues to altered mechanical function in damage and degeneration. This project will establish a novel reflected-light quantitative polarization light imaging (rQPLI) technique using a tissue analog experimental system and computational simulations. This technique will then be used to track local, mechanically-induced damage in fatigue-loaded ligament and to quantify time-dependent biologically-induced degeneration in tendon. rQPLI will overcome limitations of previous approaches and greatly advance polarization imaging for use in musculoskeletal mechanics. This study will examine intact, large-scale, full-thickness tissues that were impossible to evaluate previously, enabling detection and quantification of region-specific, microscopic, structural changes that occur during loading in real-time. This novel imaging technique will enhance optical measurement of tissue microstructure and advance polarization imaging techniques for applications in musculoskeletal biomechanics. Results will lay the foundation for future projects that further advance study of multiscale mechanics and microstructural evaluation, and enhance fundamental understanding of structure-function relationships in normal, damaged, degenerate, and healing connective tissues.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Tendons and ligaments are soft connective tissues that provide mechanical roles of force transfer and joint stabilization. Key to proper mechanical function of fiber-reinforced tissues is their specialized microstructural organization, primarily the appropriate alignment of the collagen network comprising the extracellular matrix (ECM). Determining the collagen alignment of a tissue offers a valuable means to assess functional integrity and predict mechanical response. Quantitative polarization light imaging (QPLI), a technique using transmission of polarized light through tissues, leverages an optical property called birefringence to quantify fiber alignment. This project developed a reflected light polarized light imaging technique (rQPLI) to dramatically transform the evaluation of mechanics and microstructural properties of intact soft tissue during physiological loading. The new rQPLI technique allows for advanced quantification of microstructural properties of intact soft tissues by correlating local collagen organization with region-specific mechanical properties, including during dynamic processes of damage and degeneration. Results have provided insights into the microstructural dynamics of mechanically induced damage in fatigue-loaded ligament and biologically induced degeneration in tendon. Accompanying education aims integrated research efforts with collaborative development of multimedia materials and enhance interdisciplinary training/outreach efforts to increase understanding of biomechanical applications of polarized light.

Major outcomes from this project span several topic areas: (1) technology development, (2) polarization tissue optics, (3) rQPLI for musculoskeletal applications, and (4) outreach. Details for each of these areas follow:

(1) With the advent of commercialization of the division-of-focal plane polarization sensor by Sony, we have undergone software development and assessment of the new sensor’s performance. Implementation of the commercialized sensor into rQPLI enhances the ease of translation of the technology in the future towards clinical applications. A CMOS camera from FLIR with onboard Sony polarization sensor was purchased and a custom software suite was built for the camera’s compatibility for use during rQPLI. Further, the performance of the camera was compared to the custom built one used in previous experiments and validated for future rQPLI use. 

(2) A collagen gel-based tissue analog system was used to better probe polarized light-tissue interactions during rQPLI and underlying optics that form context for data obtained during the imaging technique. First, transmission and reflectance mode polarization imaging were compared using tissue analogs of differing, but controlled alignment. Signal-to-noise analysis of rQPLI was completed to assess technique performance and outcome measures’ reliability under varying low light conditions. The noise in angle of polarization was found to be dependent on the incident light intensity and the degree of linear polarization of the incident light. The noise in the degree of linear polarization was found to depend on the intensity, degree of linear polarization, and angle of polarization of the incident light. A system of experiments assessed how individual extracellular matrix properties such as alignment, collagen density, crosslinking, and tissue opacity affect rQPLI signal. Further, computational models (object oriented, polarization sensitive Monte Carlo models) were developed to probe light-tissue interactions stochastically and iteratively. This approach allowed for manipulation of the collagen gel tissue model to observe phenomena that may be difficult to model experimentally (e.g., light penetration depth, scatterer shape, sensitivity profiles).  

(3) Studies were performed to evaluate rQPLI’s sensitivity to monitor biologically and mechanically induced degeneration in tendon/ligament. Bovine tendon was monitored continuously over a 12-hour period during progressive enzyme-mediated digestion using rQPLI and temporal microstructural changes were tracked and measured against gold standards of mechanical testing, biochemical assays and second harmonic generation imaging. In evaluating mechanically induced degeneration, we designed and built a cadaveric elbow loading apparatus capable of physiological cyclic valgus loading to induce damage to elbow ulnar collateral ligament. We also have established and validated a stereovision-based method to optically track three-dimensional strain experienced within ulnar collateral ligament during this loading process. 

(4) A module for middle school and high school students was developed centered around polarized light. A digital booklet was created that contains information about light, polarization, and how polarimetry can be used to evaluate everyday objects. We included images obtained from our own research. Additionally, we have developed three small group activities to demonstrate light polarization and make it accessible to students without a formal background in physics. This module was launched among a small group of high school students and graduate students, with intention for launch amongst middle school students soon. 

The new availability of commercial division-of-focal-plane polarimeters, together with our development of the novel reflected light-based polarization imaging technique will enable many researchers to use this technique to quantify the microstructural organization of soft tissues. Our work to validate this technique and elucidate how different tissue features impact the polarization signal will broaden the number of potential applications.
